items.title: SG agri firm sells 44.6% stake to Saudi investor for $1.8b
items.summary:
- Singapore-based Olam Group sells 44.6% stake in Olam Agri to Saudi Agricultural & Livestock Investment Co (SALIC) for US$1.78 billion.
- SALIC's ownership increases to 80.01% with the deal.
- The acquisition has a timeline of up to three years for SALIC to buy the remaining 19.99% stake.
- The transaction values Olam Agri at approximately US$4 billion and was first reported as nearing completion in November 2024.

items.title: US VC firm names ex-Goldman Sachs exec as partner in Israel
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Ibex Investors appoints Adi Dangot Zukovsky as partner in its Tel Aviv office.
- Zukovsky previously worked at Goldman Sachs and has experience from Battery Ventures and 10D Fund.
- Ibex raised US$106 million in February 2024 for its second Israeli early-stage fund, following a US$100 million fund in 2020.
- Zukovsky will collaborate with local partner Aaron Rinberg to enhance Ibex’s involvement in Israel’s startup ecosystem.

items.title: Asia layoff tracker: Job cuts hit TikTok, PropertyGuru
items.summary:
- Tech in Asia's layoff tracker shows ongoing job cuts across tech companies in Asia due to bleak fundraising and economic uncertainty.
- PropertyGuru laid off 174 employees after shutting three business units.
- CreateAI reduced its workforce by 100 after shifting focus to video games and film.
- TikTok reportedly cut down its trust and safety team in Singapore.
- Total funding in Southeast Asia, India, and China fell to $45 billion in 2024, the lowest since 2021, leading to increased layoffs as companies seek profitability.

items.title: The 50 top-funded greentech companies in Asia
Indian finance education platform eyes advisory services
items.summary:
- The 1% Club plans to launch fintech products and stock advisory services, pending approval.
- The company manages 750 crore rupees (US$86.6 million) in assets and recently introduced ‘Pillow Insurance’.
- It is applying for a research analyst license for investment recommendations as part of its expansion strategy.
- Profitable since inception, the club earned 31.4 crore (US$3.6 million) in 2024 and expects 86.9 crore rupees (US$10 million) in 2025, aided by AI-driven efficiency.

items.title: Indonesia launches Temasek-like investment arm with $20b fund
items.summary:
- Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto inaugurated the Daya Anagata Nusantara (Danantara) investment body on Feb. 24 in Jakarta.
- The launch included signing Law No. 1 of 2025 to amend existing state-owned enterprise laws and establishing Danantara’s organizational framework.
- Initial funding is projected at 326 trillion rupiah (US$20 billion) for 15 to 20 large-scale projects aimed at national economic growth, managing assets exceeding 14,710 trillion rupiah (US$900 billion).
- The body will focus on sustainable investments in renewable energy, advanced manufacturing, and food production to support an 8% GDP growth goal.

items.title: Alibaba to invest $52.4b in AI, cloud over 3 years
items.summary:
- Alibaba plans to invest 380 billion yuan (US$52.44 billion) in cloud computing and AI over the next three years.
- This investment, announced on Feb. 24, significantly surpasses its total spending in AI and cloud computing over the past decade.
- Previous plans for investment were suggested, but the amount was not specified until now.

items.title: Google’s AI video model costs $30 per minute
items.summary:
- Google announced the pricing for its AI video model Veo 2, introduced in December 2024.
- Veo 2 costs $0.50 per second, or $30 per minute, totaling $1,800 per hour.
- The model is designed to create video clips of at least two minutes long.
- For comparison, OpenAI’s Sora video model costs $200 per month for ChatGPT Pro users.

items.title: XAI’s Grok 3 faces backlash over censorship issues
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s xAI faced backlash for Grok 3 censoring mentions of Donald Trump and Musk.
- xAI's engineering lead Igor Babuschkin confirmed explicit instructions caused the issue, which was later removed.  
- By February 23, Grok 3 included Trump in its responses again after the fix.  
- The incident follows earlier concerns where Grok 3 suggested Trump and Musk deserved the death penalty, which xAI labeled a "terrible failure."  
- Musk acknowledged previous versions leaned left and promised to improve neutrality.

items.title: Digital Edge appoints group president as CEO
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- John Freeman will succeed Samuel Lee as CEO of Digital Edge starting in Q2 2023.
- Freeman has over 25 years of industry experience and previously served as chief legal and compliance officer.
- Lee will move to the role of senior advisor to the board.
- Digital Edge operates 21 data centers across Asia and has secured over US$1.6 billion in capital for expansion.
- The company aims to enhance its cloud and AI infrastructure in key markets including Japan, South Korea, India, Malaysia, Indonesia, and the Philippines.

items.title: Samsung and Intel Collaborate on AI-Powered Display Technology
items.summary:
- Samsung Display and Intel have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on February 21 to develop AI-driven display solutions.
- The partnership aims to leverage Samsung's display technology and Intel's AI accelerator chips for premium laptops and IT devices.
- Their advancements will be showcased at global exhibitions, starting with the "Humans with AI" exhibition in Seoul, featuring OLED technology and comparisons of devices.

items.title: Dubai aims to be the Silicon Valley of proptech
items.summary:
- Dubai is aiming to be a hub for property technology (proptech) innovation.
- The Dubai Land Department (DLD) is attracting entrepreneurs and funding to the sector.
- Mahmoud Al Burai stated Dubai seeks to be the 'Silicon Valley of real estate innovation'.
- The real estate market in Dubai is growing, with transactions expected to reach 761 billion dirhams (US$207.2 billion) in 2024, a 20% increase from the previous year.
- Initiatives like the Real Estate Evolution Space Initiative have been launched to drive advancements in proptech.
- DLD is exploring blockchain and AI technologies, including a Real Estate Tokenisation initiative for fractional property ownership.

items.title: German air taxi startup Lilium files for insolvency 2nd time
items.summary:
- Lilium Aerospace has filed for insolvency for the second time due to funding difficulties, announcing it would cease operations.
- The company, based in Bavaria, previously entered administration in October 2024.
- Lilium has been developing electric vertical take-off and landing (eVTOL) jets ambitious towards eco-friendly urban air mobility.
- Financial issues in the eVTOL market are widespread, affecting multiple companies including Volocopter and Vertical Aerospace.
- Lilium’s insolvency puts its agreements, including a deal for up to 100 eVTOL jets with Saudia Group, into doubt.
- Saudia had signed a binding agreement for 50 jets in July 2024, expecting deliveries by 2026. No next steps from Lilium have been disclosed.

items.title: Bybit CEO guarantees 80% of stolen ethereum recovered
items.summary:
- Bybit confirmed that 401,000 Ethereum, worth over US$1.5 billion, was stolen in a cyberattack on February 21.
- The breach targeted a cold wallet during a routine transfer; other assets were unaffected.
- CEO Ben Zhou announced that nearly 80% of the stolen Ethereum has been recovered through a bridge loan from partners.
- Withdrawals are operational but may experience delays due to checks.
- The attack is the largest in cryptocurrency history, outpacing the Ronin Network hack in 2022.
- Bybit is collaborating with legal and law enforcement to recover the stolen funds.

items.title: Oman, Golden Gate Ventures launch $100m startup fund
items.summary:
- The Oman Investment Authority (OIA) is investing through its venture capital arm, Innovation Development Oman (IDO), in a new US$100 million fund by Golden Gate Ventures (GGV).
- The fund will support startups in the Middle East, focusing on innovation and entrepreneurship.
- GGV has started regional investments by funding Bayanat, an Omani SaaS data analytics company.
- Ibrahim Said Al Eisri from OIA indicates the initiative supports Oman Vision 2040 and diversification of investments.
- GGV, founded in 2011, has invested in over 100 companies globally, including nine unicorns.

items.title: Glasswall: The things anonymous founders say about VCs
items.summary:
- The article discusses reviews from founders regarding their experiences with venture capitalists (VCs).
- It highlights the importance of transparency and feedback in VC relationships.
- Anonymous insights reveal both positive and negative experiences shared by founders, indicating a need for improvement in investor-founder dynamics.

items.title: Saudi tech firm Quantum secures $7m pre-series A
items.author: Omar Malaikah, Sara Bin Ladin
items.summary:
- Quantum, a Riyadh-based ad tech company, raised $7 million in a pre-series A funding round.
- The funding will enhance its platform and expand operations in the GCC region.
- HearstLab led the funding round, marking its first investment in the Middle East.
- Quantum was established in 2020 and aims to improve efficiency and transparency in digital advertising by connecting advertisers with publishers.

items.title: Taiwan exceeds $21b in overseas investments, led by TSMC
items.summary:
- Taiwan’s direct overseas investments reached a record US$21.05 billion in 2024.
- Growth driven by major manufacturers like TSMC, according to the central bank.
- Taiwanese residents' net overseas investments set a new record of US$31.98 billion.
- TSMC’s expansions in the US and Japan significantly contributed to this increase.

items.title: US gov’t agency to shut down 8,000 EV chargers
items.summary:
- The General Services Administration (GSA) plans to deactivate all its electric vehicle (EV) chargers across the U.S.
- An internal announcement about the shutdown is expected next week, as per a source.
- The GSA operates hundreds of EV charging stations, providing about 8,000 plugs for government and federal employees' personal vehicles.
- Regional offices have started taking chargers offline, with some stations to be turned off as early as next week.
- This move occurs under President Biden's administration, which aimed to support federal sustainability goals.
- No public statement has been released by the GSA regarding this decision.

items.title: 3 Outside-the-Box Questions That Reveal Hidden Startup Talent
items.summary:
- In 2024, 75% of employers faced challenges in filling roles, according to a Manpower Global study.
- Startups need a strategic hiring process as every hire impacts their early stage growth.
- The hiring approach at Zoko focuses on evaluating qualities that predict successful job performance rather than traditional credentials.
- Three key questions are utilized in Zoko's hiring process: 
  - Have you earned money outside a salary?
  - Have you played competitive sports?
  - Can you figure things out without a manual?
- Candidates answering 'yes' to these questions demonstrate problem-solving abilities essential for startup success.

items.title: Qatar partners with Scale AI to boost government AI
items.summary:
- Qatar signed a five-year agreement with Scale AI to enhance government operations with AI tools.
- The collaboration will focus on improving public services through predictive analytics, automation, and data analysis.
- Scale AI will evaluate over 50 potential AI applications for the Qatari government during the agreement's duration.
- Financial details of the deal remain undisclosed.

items.title: Sinking eFishery rattles bank loans
items.author: Jofie Yordan
items.summary:
- eFishery secured a US$32 million loan from DBS Indonesia three years ago.
- Recent troubles for eFishery signal a potential tightening of bank loans for startups.
- Other banks like HSBC may also reconsider their lending practices due to these developments.

items.title: Taobao launches its first physical store in Hong Kong
items.summary:
- Taobao opened its first physical store in Hong Kong on Saturday, partnering with local home repair platform Papabo.
- The store, named PapaHome, spans 2,322 square meters and is located in Tsim Sha Tsui.
- It showcases over 10,000 furniture and lifestyle products from 100 Taobao merchants, allowing customers to try out items and access details via QR codes before ordering online.

items.title: US AI search startup Genspark bags $100m, valued at $530m
items.author: Eric Jing
items.summary:
- Genspark raised US$100 million in its Series A funding round.
- The valuation of Genspark has increased to US$530 million.
- Investors from the United States and Singapore led the funding round.
- Genspark has over 2 million monthly active users.
- The startup aims to challenge Google's search dominance with its unique AI technology.
- The AI technology focuses on delivering single-answer search results with citations.
- Genspark's approach allows collaboration of multiple AI models for online research, akin to OpenAI and You.com.
- Competitor Perplexity has reached a valuation of US$9 billion.

items.title: Series SEA: Who’s investing in the region’s education startups?
items.summary:
- The article discusses the most active investors in Southeast Asia's education startup scene over the past two years.
- A constantly updated list of investors is provided, arranged by the number of deals made.
- Only firms that have invested in three or more companies during this timeframe are featured.
- The article mentions that data accuracy is a work in progress and encourages reader feedback on any inaccuracies.

items.title: Bybit offers $140m bounty after $1.4b crypto hack
items.summary:
- Bybit launched a recovery bounty program after a $1.4 billion hack on Feb. 21, 2025.
- The exchange offers 10% of any recovered funds, up to $140 million, to assistance providers.
- The hack is attributed to the North Korean Lazarus Group, who has begun laundering the stolen funds.
- Security researcher reported that the hackers moved 5,000 ETH worth about $13.7 million.
- Two recoveries have been reported, including a withdrawal blockage of 15,000 cmETH and freezing of $181,000 USDT by Tether.

items.title: US Securities Regulator Drops Coinbase Lawsuit
items.summary:
- The US SEC is withdrawing its lawsuit against Coinbase, ending a legal conflict that started in 2023.
- The lawsuit claimed Coinbase allowed trading in 13 crypto tokens that should be registered as securities and questioned its staking program compliance.
- Coinbase argued that crypto assets don't meet the legal definition of securities.
- The SEC's withdrawal indicates a shift in its cryptocurrency regulation strategy under current leadership, which includes reorganizing the crypto enforcement unit and creating an industry task force.

items.title: European tech sector surges in Q4, led by ASML, Nokia
items.summary:
- The European technology sector's earnings rose 5.5% in Q4, surpassing the 0.5% forecast.
- ASML reported strong bookings that doubled analyst expectations, spurred by AI investments.
- Nokia experienced improvements in its 5G units and anticipates increased data center demand.
- STMicroelectronics and Infineon faced struggles due to weak automotive demand and limited AI engagement.
- SAP reported a 29% increase in cloud backlog and raised its 2025 revenue forecast.
- Analysts caution about risks including potential US tariffs and economic challenges in Europe and China.

items.title: BYD Korea has no plans to sell DeepSeek-integrated cars
items.summary:
- BYD Korea will not market vehicles equipped with DeepSeek’s AI software in South Korea due to data security concerns.
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI firm, has faced restrictions in South Korea over potential data leaks to China.
- BYD's AI-integrated models are designated only for the Chinese market, and BYD Korea will comply with local regulations.
- Personal data collected in South Korea will remain secure and won't be transferred to China.
- BYD Korea has successfully launched the Atto 3 electric SUV, which does not include DeepSeek’s technology.

items.title: Capital SEA: Southeast Asia’s funding landscape
items.author: Yeo Cheng Yong, Terence Lee
items.summary:
- The article analyzes the funding landscape in Southeast Asia, addressing investor activity and funding trends.
- It consists of two sections: **Weekly Update**, which highlights recent investor activity, and **Macro Trends**, showcasing country-wide funding distributions.
- Access to detailed data requires a subscription, indicating premium content availability.

items.title: BMW reviews UK Mini EV production timeline
Fintech giants expand services despite stock volatility
items.summary:
- The fintech sector is seeing convergence as Block, Affirm, and PayPal expand services.
- Block missed earnings estimates, resulting in an 18% stock drop, but is integrating new services through Afterpay acquisition.
- Affirm exceeded earnings expectations with a 22% stock surge, reporting US$10.1 billion in gross merchandise volume.
- Affirm's active users grew by 23%, and the Affirm Card user base increased by 136% year-over-year.
- PayPal reported US$437.8 billion in total payment volume, focusing on Venmo for merchant transactions to compete with Apple Pay and Shop Pay.

items.title: Tencent reshuffle AI apps as competition heats up
items.summary:
- Tencent reorganizes several AI applications into its Cloud & Smart Industries Group (CSIG) due to rising competition.
- Affected apps include QQ Browser, Sogou Pinyin keyboard, and learning assistant Ima, originally under the Platform & Content Group.
- The AI chatbot Yuanbao was also moved to CSIG from the Technology Engineering Group.
- The restructuring was confirmed by a Tencent representative on February 21, focusing on integrating AI into practical applications and enhancing monetization.
- Analyst Zhang Yi notes this shift aims to refine product experience and leverage user feedback amid competition from rivals like Alibaba and Baidu.

items.title: Xpeng expands to 60 markets by 2025
items.summary:
- Xpeng plans to expand its international markets from 30 to 60 by the end of 2025, as announced by CEO He Xiaopeng on Feb. 22.
- The company has started its first global shipment of the X9, sending 300 right-hand drive units to Thailand.
- Currently, only the G6 model is available in Thailand, with more models to be introduced.
- Xpeng is enhancing its charging infrastructure with ultra-fast charging stations set for Thailand and Hong Kong by early 2025.
- The company will begin testing its autonomous driving system in international markets this year, with a goal for self-driving vehicles by 2026.
- Xpeng's 'go-global 2.0 strategy' will include markets in the Middle East and Africa, in addition to Europe and Southeast Asia.
- International sales accounted for 13% of total sales in 2024, aiming to reach 50% by 2027.

items.title: Indian furniture retailer Pepperfry’s revenue drops 31% in FY24
items.summary:
- Pepperfry reported a 31% drop in operational revenue for FY24, falling to ₹188.9 crore (US$21.8 million).
- Total income decreased by 28% year-on-year to ₹209.2 crore (US$24.14 million).
- Net loss narrowed by 37.4% to ₹117.5 crore (US$13.56 million), and EBITDA loss decreased by 52.2% to ₹43.6 crore (US$5.03 million).
- Total expenditures dropped 31.1% to ₹326.7 crore (US$37.70 million).
- Employee expenses were cut by 29.7%, and marketing costs were reduced by nearly 45%.
- Founded in 2012, Pepperfry operates in 173 cities with over 200 studios.
- The company has raised over US$305 million, and announced plans for an IPO were shelved in 2024 amid stagnant sales.
- Originally aiming for 10-15% revenue growth in FY25, the path to profitability remains uncertain.

items.title: Court filings reveal Meta staff debated copyrighted content
items.summary:
- Unsealed court documents in the Kadrey v. Meta case disclose that Meta employees discussed the use of copyrighted content to train AI models.
- A research engineer suggested purchasing e-books at retail prices for speed, despite legal concerns.
- Meta considered using Libgen for accessing copyrighted books and debated how to avoid public acknowledgment of such actions.
- Some insiders at Meta argued that existing data from Facebook and Instagram might not suffice for advanced AI training, driving a push for more extensive datasets, even against previous decisions regarding copyrighted content.
- The Kadrey v. Meta case, initiated in 2023 in California, accuses Meta of analyzing both pirated and licensed books for potential licensing negotiations.

items.title: OpenAI to shift 75% of data centers to Stargate by 2030
items.summary:
- OpenAI plans to move 75% of its data centers to the Stargate infrastructure by 2030.
- This shift aims to enhance efficiency and reduce operational costs.
- The transition is part of OpenAI's broader strategy to optimize its cloud computing resources.

items.title: NetEase cuts jobs, projects as growth remains slow
items.summary:
- NetEase Inc. is undergoing major restructuring, led by CEO William Ding, involving significant job cuts and project halts.
- The company is canceling around a dozen games and shutting down international studios including Ouka, Worlds Untold, and Jar of Sparks, affecting fewer than 60 employees.
- New investments in gaming studios and IPs have been paused since early 2024, alongside a reduced global investment team.
- Despite a 1.5% revenue growth in gaming, gross profit declined by 2.6%, with overall growth slow at single-digit increases in the past two years.
- The game Marvel Rivals generated over US$200 million and attracted more than 40 million users since December.

items.title: Uber CEO says Tesla rejects partnership for robotaxi plans
items.summary:
- Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi confirmed Tesla will launch its robotaxi service independently.
- Discussions between Uber and Tesla CEO Elon Musk ended with Tesla choosing a solo strategy.
- Tesla's decision makes it a competitor to Uber and Waymo, which plans to launch autonomous rides in Austin next month.
- Uber has formed over 12 partnerships with self-driving firms since 2023, but Tesla will not integrate with Uber's platform.
- Khosrowshahi expressed hope that Tesla's participation could stabilize demand in the autonomous vehicle market.

items.title: ByteDance valued over $400b by major investors
items.summary:
- ByteDance has been valued at over US$400 billion by major investors, recovering from a low of US$275 billion in mid-2022.
- Valuations included US$410 billion by Fidelity Investments and US$450 billion by T. Rowe Price Group.
- Estimates based on SEC filings exclude TikTok's US operations due to ongoing ban concerns.
- The increase in valuation is driven by strong revenue growth and the potential of its AI chatbot, Doubao, which has 75 million active users.
- Recovery of China's tech sector, aided by AI advancements and regulatory easing, contributed to the rise.

items.title: Asia’s tech investors with the highest exit rates
items.summary:
- The article provides insights on tech investors in Asia known for high exit rates.
- Exits can occur through mergers, secondary sales, or public listings, but high exit rates signal only partial success.
- Later-stage investors often have better exit rates due to lower risk and higher liquidity in their investments.
- A strong local market can facilitate exits for startups in certain countries.
- The article hints that some investors listed may be outperforming expectations in their exit strategies.
- Readers can access additional data through linked charts and a database of companies.

items.title: If you build it, will they come?
items.summary:
- Neolix, an autonomous vehicle company in Beijing, raised US$137 million in a series C round.
- Dream, an AI security firm from Israel, raised US$100 million in series B funding.
- Indian B2B ecommerce firm Udaan secured US$75 million in funding from existing investors.
- Healing Paper from South Korea raised nearly US$30 million in series C funding.
- Japanese salon company Salowin obtained almost US$18 million in debt financing.

items.title: These are the most active investors in Japan’s startups
items.summary:
- The article lists the most active investors in Japan’s startups over the past two years.
- Investors are ranked by the number of deals made with Japan-based startups.
- Only firms that have invested in three or more companies in Japan within the last 12 months are featured.

items.title: Alibaba makes artificial general intelligence its focus
items.summary:
- Alibaba CEO Eddie Wu announces focus on artificial general intelligence (AGI).
- Enhancing intelligence models is key to Alibaba's long-term vision towards AI.
- Company declares itself an AI-driven entity while maintaining e-commerce as a central focus.
- Alibaba's cloud services revenue rose 13% last quarter, with AI-related products seeing triple-digit growth.
- Plans to significantly increase investment in cloud and AI infrastructure over the next three years.
- Alibaba's US shares rose 11% in premarket trading following the announcement.

items.title: YouTube introduces ‘premium lite’ for ad-free videos
items.summary:
- YouTube launches ‘premium lite,’ a lower-cost tier for ad-free access to podcasts and non-music videos.
- Rolling out in the US, Australia, Germany, and Thailand, this tier allows ads in music videos unlike the higher-priced YouTube Premium plan.
- The offering aims to provide users more flexibility and was previously tested in select markets; pricing and release date are undisclosed.
- The launch responds to increasing competition in video and podcast markets, impacting YouTube creators' revenue as platforms like Spotify explore monetization strategies.

items.title: Suzuki shifts to hybrids, cuts EV plans
items.summary:
- Suzuki Motor is reducing investment in new EVs and focusing more on hybrids due to declining demand in India and Europe.
- Planned EV models for India cut from 6 to 4, and for Europe from 5 to 4 by fiscal 2030.
- The company aims for annual sales of 8 trillion yen (US$53 billion) by fiscal 2030, enhancing hybrid production instead.
- In India, Suzuki plans to boost natural gas vehicle sales and expand local production for exports.
- This strategy follows broader industry trends, with other automakers like Honda and Subaru increasing their hybrid commitments.

items.title: Japan looks to Vietnam for semiconductor talent
items.summary:
- Japanese semiconductor manufacturers are seeking talent in Vietnam to address labor shortages.
- A delegation from Japan's Kyushu region visited Hanoi to discuss hiring opportunities with local IT companies and universities.
- Vietnamese engineers possess basic training, beneficial for business expansion in the semiconductor sector.
- Vietnam's population is 100 million, with a median age in the early thirties, offering a strong talent pool.
- The Vietnamese government aims to train 50,000 semiconductor workers by 2030.
- Vietnam is also attracting attention from other tech giants, such as Samsung and Nvidia, which are expanding in the country.

items.title: A list of fundraising startups from Asia and beyond (Updated)
items.summary:
- Fundraising is challenging, leading to the compilation of a list of fundraising startups.
- Startups can sign up to be listed and get exposure to investors.
- Investors can opt-in to receive information about curated fundraising startups through subscription.

items.title: Dubai to launch first driverless taxis by early 2026
items.author: Mansoor Alfalasi
items.summary:
- Dubai Taxi Company (DTC) plans to launch its first driverless taxi service by early 2026.
- The initiative aims to address regulatory, safety, and operational needs in collaboration with the Roads and Transport Authority (RTA).
- Testing will begin in early 2026, with initial deployment areas to be selected by the RTA.
- Dubai has commenced advancements in autonomous mobility with supervised testing starting in 2023, and plans to introduce electric air taxis as well.
- Abu Dhabi already has operational driverless taxis, with a commercial service launched on Yas Island by Uber and WeRide in December.
- DTC expanded its fleet by 744 vehicles last year, reaching a total of 5,960, with further expansion planned for 2025.

items.title: Bybit hit by largest crypto heist, loses $1.5b
items.summary:
- Bybit experienced a security breach leading to the theft of $1.5 billion in digital assets, marking the largest crypto heist in history.
- Hackers targeted the exchange's cold wallet, and funds were primarily in ether.
- The stolen funds were moved through multiple wallets before being liquidated.
- This breach surpasses the previous notable hacks including Poly Network ($611 million) and Binance ($570 million).
- The perpetrators were identified as North Korea's Lazarus Group, known for targeting crypto platforms since 2017.
- Bybit's CEO Ben Zhou confirmed the security of other cold wallets and that withdrawals continue normally.
- Bybit secured a bridge loan from undisclosed partners to cover the losses.
